title: Belgium says loot boxes are gambling, wants them banned in europe

embed.description: Last week, Belgium's Gaming Commission announced that it had launched an investigation into whether the loot boxes available for purchase in games like Overwatch and Star Wars Battlefront 2 constitute a form of gambling. Today, VTM news reported that the ruling is in, and the answer is yes.

Loot boxes are a cancer on modern gaming where the experience of the game is secondary to the profits to be made by exploiting vulnerable teenagers.

So I've looked at some of the material in the links Essembie provided and it seems there's a bit more to consider than "lootboxes are gambling" and "lootboxes are fine". Specifically, there's an opinion of "lootboxes that impede gameplay and/or game progress are wrong".

So we have the Belgian Gaming Commission (which I'll just call the BGC) who want to ban *all* lootboxes in games, whether they impede game progress (for example, LoL) , create a pay-to-win environment (for example, Battlefront 2) or are based around purely aesthetic virtual items (for example, Overwatch). On the other hand, the Victorian Gambling Authority (VGA) are focused only on those systems that impede game progress (LoL) or create a pay-to-win environment (Battlefront 2).

Personally, I think the VGA has the better idea here. There are a lot of games that rely on aesthetic-based lootbox systems to make their profits, and it works well as a way to create an enjoyable free-to-play/win platform for a game. That said, I do think the BGC has a point, in the sense that such lootbox systems should have some kind of clarity surrounding them, such as making it clear to the players what chance they have of getting a specific item from a specific kind of lootbox.

Honestly, I'm kind of hoping that Riot will come out with some kind of statement soon on how they plan to move forward now that the whole "lootboxes are gambling" issues has come, well, "out of the box", and give the players an idea of what they can expect to change in order for Riot to conform with not only the Gamer's opinions on the whole "lootbox" issue, but now also how various governing bodies are looking upon the issue.

I argue that tcg booster packs are not gambling. 
For one gambling is the wagering of money or item of value on an uncertain outcome with the primary intent on winning additional money or goods.
So when you buy a tcg booster pack, you are buying a a set number of random cards. The primary intent of the transaction is the exchange of money for goods with the certain outcome of gaining cards. It doesn't matter if those cards have a worth on a secondary market. 
TL;DR Gambling is based on a transaction where the outcome is uncertain. Buying a booster pack is not uncertain because you know you are getting cards.

As for loot boxes, hextech chests, etc the key defense each company will use is that in their terms of service the in-game currency used to buy these items have no value, monetary or otherwise (E.G. Riot section IV EULA, sections 4.3 and 4.4 Terms of Use). So using in-game currency to buy these items of uncertain content is not gambling according to law.

The outcome of a Card pack are uncertain, because you don't know what is in the pack.

It's gambling man.

And not to mention, you can use in game currency, but fact is that is a loophole, and is still gambling.

You have certainty in that the pack will contain X number of cards. Again we are also looking at the primary intent of the transaction. When you buy a pack, you are exchanging a set value of money for goods in the form of cards. The primary intention of the transaction the acquisition of goods, there is no chance for gaining additional money or goods (unless it has been strictly stated before hand as part of a competition, which comes under regulations). There is no wagering involved in the process.

Look at it this way. The game company does not set the monetary value of individual cards. It is the secondary market that does so. If there was no secondary market then the cards would have no intrinsic value. 

It is perceived as gambling because of the value people outside the company have assigned to the individual cards themselves.
